title: Utilizing the {cards} and {cardx} packages in the QC Workflow

library(chevron)

title: Adverse Events (AET02)
section: Building an AET02 table using the {cards} package
text:
Building an AET02 table using the {cards} package
In this example below we perform different data pre-processing for the different ARDs we want to create. We then generate separate ARDs for the different sections of the AET02 table and then merge them all together.


Show the code
library(cards)

title: Adverse Events (AET02)
text:
Comparing Outputs
Upon comparing the two outputs, it’s evident that both methods yield identical values, enabling their use for Quality Control (QC) purposes.

title: Demographics and Baseline Characteristics (DMT01)
section: Building an DMT01 table using the {cards} package
text:
Building an DMT01 table using the {cards} package
In this example below we create the same demographics table using the {gtsummary} package, with the same data set provided by the {chevron} package.


Show the code
library(cards)

# build ARDs that calculate relevant statistics for continuous and categorical variables.

ards <- bind_ard(ard_continuous(syn_data$adsl, variables = c(AGE), by = ARM),
                 ard_categorical(syn_data$adsl, variables = c(AGEGR1, SEX, ETHNIC, RACE), by = ARM))

title: Demographics and Baseline Characteristics (DMT01)
text:
Comparing Outputs


Show the code
# Equality in means and sd

mean_tbl <- results |>
  dplyr::filter(label_name %in% "Mean (SD)") |>
  dplyr::select(9:11) |>
  dplyr::mutate(across(everything(), ~purrr::map_chr(.x, ~paste(.x, collapse = ", "))))

mean_ard <- ards %>%
  dplyr::filter(stat_name %in% c("mean", "sd")) %>%
  dplyr::summarise(
    "Mean(SD)" = paste(stat[stat_name == "mean"], "(", stat[stat_name == "sd"], ")", sep = ""))


Warning: Returning more (or less) than 1 row per `summarise()` group was deprecated in
dplyr 1.1.0.
ℹ Please use `reframe()` instead.
ℹ When switching from `summarise()` to `reframe()`, remember that `reframe()`
  always returns an ungrouped data frame and adjust accordingly.


Show the code
mean_tbl


                           A: Drug X                         B: Placebo
1 31.3333333333333, 5.25991127935317 35.0666666666667, 9.02747130126915
         C: Combination
1 36.6, 6.4453748644169




Show the code
mean_ard


# A tibble: 3 × 1
  `Mean(SD)`                        
  <chr>                             
1 31.3333333333333(5.25991127935317)
2 35.0666666666667(9.02747130126915)
3 36.6(6.4453748644169)             




Show the code
# Equality in n, N and percent

cat_tbl <- results |>
  dplyr::filter(avar_name %in% "RACE") |>
  dplyr::select(c(3,9:11)) |>
  dplyr::mutate(across(everything(), ~purrr::map_chr(.x, ~paste(.x, collapse = ", "))))

cat_tbl


  avar_name            A: Drug X            B: Placebo        C: Combination
1      RACE                   15                    15                    15
2      RACE                 0, 0  2, 0.133333333333333 1, 0.0666666666666667
3      RACE 8, 0.533333333333333 10, 0.666666666666667  8, 0.533333333333333
4      RACE 4, 0.266666666666667 1, 0.0666666666666667  4, 0.266666666666667
5      RACE               3, 0.2  2, 0.133333333333333  2, 0.133333333333333




Show the code
cat_ard <- ards %>%
  dplyr::filter(variable %in% c("RACE")) |>
  dplyr::filter(stat_name %in% c("n", "N", "p")) 

cat_ard


{cards} data frame: 36 x 11


   group1 group1_level variable variable_level stat_name stat_label  stat
1     ARM    A: Drug X     RACE      AMERICAN…         n          n     0
2     ARM    A: Drug X     RACE      AMERICAN…         N          N    15
3     ARM    A: Drug X     RACE      AMERICAN…         p          %     0
4     ARM    B: Place…     RACE      AMERICAN…         n          n     2
5     ARM    B: Place…     RACE      AMERICAN…         N          N    15
6     ARM    B: Place…     RACE      AMERICAN…         p          % 0.133
7     ARM    C: Combi…     RACE      AMERICAN…         n          n     1
8     ARM    C: Combi…     RACE      AMERICAN…         N          N    15
9     ARM    C: Combi…     RACE      AMERICAN…         p          % 0.067
10    ARM    A: Drug X     RACE          ASIAN         n          n     8


ℹ 26 more rows

ℹ 4 more variables: context, fmt_fn, warning, error


Upon comparing the two outputs, it’s evident that both methods yield identical values, enabling their use for Quality Control (QC) purposes.

title: QCing with {cards} and {cardx}
text:
QCing with {cards} and {cardx}
This catalog is meant to demo the use of ARD-centric packages within the Quality Control workflow. Verification of statistics generated with NEST packages (such as: {tern}, {rtables}, {chevron}) can be verified by reproducing the tables using Analysis Results Dataset (ARDs).
